physical_examinations.vital_signs: Blood pressure: 136/91 mm Hg; other vital signs were normal.
physical_examinations.relevant_findings: On examination, the patient appeared well nourished and well groomed. Dystonia of the left arm and leg was present, with no useful grasp. Occasional pulling of the neck. The left leg was mildly dys-tonic; she walked briskly and unaided, with a slight abnormality in gait. There were intermittent movements of her left arm at rest.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: 14 months after initial evaluation, episodes of difficulty speaking, swallowing, and moving facial muscles developed. The speech was halting but clear, and facial movements were slow but intact.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Cognition was normal. Mildly clumsy during personal hygiene activities, ate independently with sensory tricks. Normal coordination except for diminished left hand function.
The total score on the Burke–Fahn–Marsden Dystonia Rating Scale was 30 out of 120, with severe dystonia of the left arm, no useful grasp, and mild dystonia of the left leg. The gait was wide-based.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: One month later, examination revealed mildly decreased facial expression and a markedly abnormal gait.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Vocalization was irregular in pitch, and great effort was required to generate minimal sound. Cranial nerves II through XII were intact. Flexible nasolaryngoscopic evaluation showed intact arytenoid mobility, smooth vocal-cord edges bilaterally, and no masses or ulcerations.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Vocal cords had incomplete adduction and multiple irregular and non-volitional movements during phonation.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: There was a marked improvement in speech after botulinum toxin injections into the larynx.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Continued benefit from multiple injections over the next intervals.
